questions.text: What type of nerve is the facial nerve?
questions.solution: The facial nerve is a mixed cranial nerve which contains both sensory and motor part. It is the 7th cranial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The general somatic efferent is not a component of the facial nerve.

Components of the facial nerve:

  • Special visceral efferent - motor to muscles of facial expression (derived from branchial arches, hence special visceral and not general somatic like the other muscles)
  • General visceral efferent - secretomotor to lacrimal and submandibular glands
  • Special visceral afferent - taste from anterior 2/3rd tongue
  • General somatic afferent - general sensations from pinna, external auditory canal, and tympanic membrane.

questions.text: In a patient with an acoustic neuroma involving the sensory division of the facial nerve, the Hitzelberger sign was positive. What is the other name for this nerve?
questions.solution:
The sensory division of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg. The facial nerve is a mixed nerve having the motor and a sensory root.

Hitzelberger sign refers to hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in acoustic neuroma due to the compression of the facial nerve.

Option A: Jacobson’s nerve - the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve). It is associated with glomus tympanicum.

Option B: Arnold’s nerve - the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve).

Option D: Herring’s nerve - the carotid sinus branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve).

questions.text: You are performing the cranial nerve examination in a patient with a stroke. You noticed a loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. What is this sensation carried by?
questions.solution:
The taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the special visceral afferent of the facial nerve via chorda tympani nerve.

The taste sensation from the hard and soft palate is also carried by the facial nerve via the greater superficial petrosal nerve to the nucleus tractus solitarius.

questions.text: A patient with the following findings is presented to you. Where is the motor nucleus of the involved cranial nerve is located?
questions.solution: The given image shows left-sided lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy and the motor nucleus is located in the pons. It is located along with abducens and vestibulocochlear nerve nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the course of the facial nerve in the pons?

choices.text: It hooks around the 8th nerve nucleus
It hooks around the 6th nerve nucleus
It exits the pons at ponto-pyramidal junction

questions.solution:
The facial nerve in the pons hooks around the 6th (abducens) nerve nucleus. 

It exits the pons ventrally at the pontomedullary (ponto-olivary) junction. It then runs in the cerebellopontine angle to reach the internal auditory meatus.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the first genu of the facial nerve?

choices.text: Contains a ganglion which supplies the lacrimal gland
Gives the first branch of the facial nerve
Lies on the posterior wall of the middle ear
Between the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus and the geniculate ganglion.

questions.solution:
The 1st genu of the facial nerve lies on the medial wall of the middle ear and not posterior wall.

It is formed at the geniculate ganglion when the facial nerve from the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus takes a turn posteriorly. Then the facial nerve continues as a tympanic or horizontal segment.

It homes the geniculate ganglion which supplies the lacrimal gland (via greater superficial petrosal nerve). It gives off the first branch of the facial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is true for the 2nd genu of the facial nerve?

choices.text: It gives the second branch of the facial nerve
It lies on the inferior wall of the middle ear
It is at the junction of 3rd and 4th intratemporal segments

questions.solution:
The 2nd genu of the facial nerve lies at the junction of the 3rd and the 4th intratemporal segments, between the tympanic and the mastoid segments.

The 2nd genu of the facial nerve is formed where the horizontal facial nerve takes a turn inferiorly at the junction between the medial and posterior walls of the middle ear.

It continues as the vertical segment of the facial nerve behind the posterior wall of the middle ear. It does not contain a ganglion and does not give any branches.

The course of the facial nerve has 3 parts-

  • Intracranial
  • Intratemporal
  • Extracranial.

Intratemporal part of the facial nerve has 4 segments-

  • Meatal
  • Labyrinthine
  • Tympanic/horizontal
  • Mastoid/vertical segments.

Option A: Gasserian ganglion is present in the trigeminal nerve.

Option B: The temporal segment of the facial nerve ends with the 2nd genu. The nerve then passes vertically downward to form the mastoid segment. The 2nd branch of facial nerve (nerve to stapedius) arises from this segment close to the level of 2nd genu and not from the 2nd genu.

questions.text: Which of the following is the shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve is the labyrinthine segment (length 4.0 mm, diameter 0.61–0.68 mm).

The labyrinthine segment is from the fundus of meatus to the geniculate ganglion where the nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter  and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus edema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.

Related Pearl: Parts of Intratemporal Division of Facial Nerve

Segment Within From To Length (mm) Remarks
Meatal Internal Acoustic Meatus Porus acousticus (medial end of IAM) Fundus (lateral end of IAM) 8-10 Only intra-temporal segment that is not within fallopian canal
Labyrinthine Fallopian canal Fundus 1st genu/ geniculate ganglion 3-5 Shortest and the narrowest
Tympanic/ Horizontal Fallopian canal 1st genu 2nd genu 11 Runs on medial wall of middle ear
Mastoid/ Vertical Fallopian canal 2nd genu Stylomastoid foramen 13 Runs in posterior wall of middle ear

questions.text: In the examination of a patient with facial nerve palsy, the Schirmer test was positive. Involvement of which of the following branches of the facial nerve is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Involvement of the greater superficial petrosal nerve causes a decrease in lacrimation, detected by the Schirmer test.

It is the first branch of the facial nerve and arises from the geniculate ganglion. It carries secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland and the glands of nasal mucosa and palate.

questions.text: A young man who underwent surgery for chronic suppurative otitis media presented with a loss of taste sensation. Which segment of the facial nerve gives rise to the involved branch?
questions.solution:
The injury to chorda tympani nerve produces loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and it arises from the mastoid or vertical segment of the facial nerve.

Chorda tympani nerve carries the taste sensation from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. It is a branch of the facial nerve arising from the mastoid/vertical segment after the nerve to stapedius before exiting the stylomastoid foramen. It relays in the nucleus of tractus solitarius.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for congenital dehiscence of the fallopian canal?
questions.solution:
The congenital dehiscence (absence of bony cover) of the fallopian canal of the facial nerve occurs most commonly in the tympanic or horizontal segment over the oval window.

It is the most common anomaly of the facial canal. A dehiscent nerve is prone to injury at the time of surgery. It gets easily compressed or inflamed in mastoid and middle ear infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The frontal branch is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve.

The five terminal branches of the facial nerve are:

  • Temporal
  • Zygomatic
  • Buccal
  • Mandibular
  • Cervical

The extratemporal course of the facial nerve starts at the stylomastoid foramen where it exits the temporal bone and runs anteriorly to enter the substance of the parotid gland.

Here it divides into 2 main terminal trunks, the temporofacial and the cervicofacial. These further divide and re-anastomose to give the five terminal branches.

questions.text: A patient with an acoustic neuroma at the cerebellopontine angle presents with a facial nerve palsy. Which of the following muscles will not be paralyzed in this case?
questions.solution:
Anterior belly of digastric is not paralyzed in facial nerve palsy.

Muscles supplied by facial nerve:

  • Nerve to stapedius - stapedius muscle.
  • Posterior auricular nerve - muscles of the pinna and the occipital belly of occipitofrontalis.
  • Muscular branches - stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric.
  • Terminal branches - muscles of facial expression.

questions.text: The facial nerve is not supplied by which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
Facial artery does not supply the facial nerve 

Vascular Supply of facial nerve:

  • Anterior-inferior cerebellar artery supplies the nerve in the cerebellopontine angle
  • Labyrinthine artery, a branch of the anterior-inferior cerebellar artery  supplies the nerve in the internal auditory canal
  • Superficial petrosal artery, a branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies geniculate ganglion and the adjacent region
  • Stylomastoid artery, a branch of the posterior auricular artery supplies the mastoid segment.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident assisting on a modified radical mastoidectomy in a patient with cholesteatoma. Which of the following landmarks will not help you to identify the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Posterior semicircular canal is not used as a surgical landmark to identify the facial nerve.

Surgical Landmarks of the facial nerve for middle ear and mastoid surgery:

  • Processus cochleariformis - It demarcates the geniculate ganglion which lies just anterior to it. The tympanic segment of the nerve starts at this level.
  • Oval window and horizontal semicircular canal - The horizontal segment of the facial nerve runs above the oval window (stapes) and below the horizontal/lateral semicircular canal.
  • Short process of incus - The vertical segment of the facial nerve lies medial to the short process of incus at the level of aditus.
  • Pyramid - The vertical segment of the facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and the posterior tympanic sulcus.

questions.text: While performing a parotidectomy, which of the following landmarks would you use to identify the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Tragus is used as a surgical landmark to identify facial nerve in parotid surgery.

Surgical landmarks of the facial nerve for parotid surgery:

  • Tragal pointer -  triangular inferior portion of the tragus. The main trunk lies 1 cm deep to it.
  • Tympanomastoid suture - the main trunk lies 6-8 mm deep to it.
  • Styloid process - the nerve lies lateral to it
  • Posterior belly of digastric attachment at the digastric groove - the nerve can be found emerging from the stylomastoid foramen under the muscle but lateral to the styloid process.

questions.text: While performing mastoid exploration, which of the following is not useful in preventing the injury to the facial nerve?

choices.text: Drilling parallel to course of nerve

questions.solution:
A larger burr is used to prevent facial nerve injury in the mastoid exploration and not a smaller burr.

Measures to reduce facial nerve injury during mastoid exploration:

  • Good anatomical knowledge
  • Working parallel to the nerve, never at an angle.
  • Use the biggest burr available. Smaller burrs are more harmful.
  • Constant irrigation prevents thermal injury
  • Granulations present over the facial nerve are best left alone.
  • Good magnification.
